pebbleProof.title: Pebble Proof
pebbleProof.description: Count pebbles forming squares on each side.

myia.name: Myia
dialogues: My father loves triangles. He found that rectangles can be described as the combination of two triangles. These are special triangles, because they have an angle of 90 degrees. We call them right triangles.

When we make squares from the sides of a right triangle, the pebbles in the smaller squares add up perfectly to form the square of the longest sideâ€”the hypotenuseâ€”so we write it as aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ². Click 'Animate Proof' to see them move!
Do you see? The pebbles in the two smaller squares perfectly equal the number of pebbles in the largest! Try this with another triangle.

1.title: Step 1: The Known Dimension
1.narrative: First, measure what is plain to see: the length of one of the pyramid's base edges.

2.title: Step 2: Finding the Center
2.narrative: To find the height, we need a right triangle with two known sides. The hidden triangle begins at the midpoint of a base edge.
2.question: What is the length from a corner to the midpoint â€” i.e., half the base? (A cubit is an ancient unit of measurement roughly equal to the length of a forearm.)
2.feedback: Correct. This is the first length of our hidden triangle: 205.5 cubits.

3.title: Step 3: The Inner Dimension
3.narrative: Because the base is a square, that half-base equals the distance from the center to the midpoint. This is a leg of the triangle.
3.question: This internal line forms which part of the hidden right triangle?

4.title: Step 4: The Slant Height
4.narrative: Now measure the slant height from the midpoint on the face to the apex.
4.question: This measurable slant height represents which part of the hidden triangle?(An apex is the highest point or vertex of a pyramid.)
4.feedback: Indeed. It is the hypotenuse, the longest side.

5.title: Step 5: The Unseen Height
5.narrative: The triangle is now revealed. You have leg 'a' (205.5) and hypotenuse 'c' (342.5). The final, unmeasurable side is the one we seek: the true vertical height, leg 'b'.
5.question: To solve for this unknown height (leg 'b'), how must we rearrange the theorem aÂ² + bÂ² = cÂ²?
5.feedback: The path is clear. Now, you must perform the calculation.

6.title: Step 6: The Method
6.narrative: You now have the formula: bÂ² = cÂ² - aÂ². To find the height 'b' itself, what must you do next?
6.question: How do you solve for b?
6.feedback: Yes! You must take the square root of both sides to reveal the true height.

7.title: Step 7: Squaring the Triangle
7.narrative: Your formula is bÂ² = cÂ² - aÂ². You know the slant 'c' is 342.5 and the half-base 'a' is 205.5. 342.5Â² - 205.5Â² is equal to 75,076.
7.question: What does 75,076 represent?

options.option3: The square root of the height

7.feedback: Yes, this is the square of the unknown height of the triangle.

8.title: Step 8: The Final Dimension
8.narrative: You have found bÂ² = 75,076. Now, release the true height from its squared form.
8.question: What is the square root of 75,076?
8.feedback: The pyramid reveals its hidden dimension. The true height is precisely 274 cubits.

9.title: Step 9: The Secret Ratio
9.narrative: Behold the dimensions: Half-base 205.5, Height 274, Slant 342.5. Divide all by 68.5 and see the harmony.
9.question: These three lengths form a near-perfect whole number ratio. What is that sacred ratio (Half-base : Height : Slant)?
9.feedback: Yes! The 3-4-5 triangle. You see now? The pyramid is not just stone, but a monument to universal mathematical harmony.

waterProof.title: Pouring Proof
waterProof.description: Pour water from squares to show equal areas.

myia.name: Myia
dialogues: My father wanted to prove his theorem works for all right triangles, not just those with whole numbers. Watch how water reveals this universal truth.
Each squareâ€™s area equals the square of its side length. The waterâ€™s volume perfectly represents that areaâ€”it can fill any shape, unlike pebbles that only work with whole numbers.
Now pour the water from both smaller squares into the largest one. Watch carefully as the areas combine and fill it exactly!
This proves the theoremâ€™s true powerâ€”it works for every right triangle, no matter what numbers you choose.

dissectionProof.title: Dissection Proof
dissectionProof.description: Rearrange triangle pieces to show equal areas.

myia.name: Myia
dialogues: Here is the most elegant proof of allâ€”it uses no numbers, no counting, just pure geometric reasoning that convinced even the greatest scholars.
Look at these four identical right triangles arranged around the tilted green square. This green area represents cÂ², the square of the hypotenuse.
Now rearrange the same four triangles to the corners. They surround two separate squaresâ€”one blue square for aÂ² and one orange square for bÂ².

The magic is that we used exactly the same pieces in both arrangements! Since the triangles occupy the same space, the remaining areas must be equal. Youâ€™ve just proven aÂ²+bÂ²=cÂ² using pure logic and shapes.

dissectionProof.proof3InfoBody: This proof dissects the right triangle and rearranges the pieces to form two smaller squares that combine to equal the area of the larger square.

titleScreen.title: Pythagoras Quest: The Apprentice of Croton
titleScreen.subtitle: As a new apprentice, you'll discover the mathematical secrets that revolutionized our understanding of numbers, music, and geometry. Master the famous Pythagorean Theorem through hands-on experiments and become one of the Mathematikoiâ€”the keepers of mathematical wisdom.

dialogues: The year is 520 BCE. In the bustling Greek colony of Croton, Italy, a school unlike any other has taken root, founded by the legendary thinker and lover of wisdom, Pythagoras. You are a new apprentice seeking knowledge, and to join the inner circle of Mathematikoi, you must first pass the initiationsâ€”your guide is waiting.

myia.name: Myia
dialogues: Welcome, Apprentice. Iâ€™m Myia, daughter of Pythagoras. My father taught that numbers are the hidden language of the worldâ€”everything from the seasons to the stars follows patterns that numbers reveal. By understanding these patterns, we understand the universe itself.
Before us stands the Wisdom Hub. It opens only when you decide which knowledge to seek first. Will you unlock the door with the harmony of music or with the hidden patterns of numbers?

myia.name: Myia
dialogues: Welcome, apprentice! To find the perfect ladder length, we must first understand the shape we're dealing with. The wall, the ground, and the ladder form a right-angled triangle!
Excellent. Now that we know the hypotenuse (which we call 'c'), we can use the Pythagorean Theorem. Which of these is the correct formula?
Let's put the formula to work. We'll start with side 'a', the height of the wall. What is its value squared?
Good. Now for side 'b', the width of the moat. Let's find its square.
We have aÂ² and bÂ². Now, we must add them together to find the value of cÂ².
One final step! We know cÂ², but we need 'c'â€”the actual ladder length. Find the square root.
Brilliant! You've mastered the theorem. By breaking down the problem, you have solved the challenge. Well done!

myia.name: Myia
dialogues: How can you use the Pythagorean Theorem to find the height of this Great Pyramid? Using only a measurement rope and your reason, you can uncover this hidden truth...First, we should measure what is plain to see: The length of one of the pyramid's base edges.

To find the height, we need to find a right triangle with two known sides. The base of the pyramid is not the base of the triangleâ€” Yet, the hidden triangle we seek starts from the midpoint of this edge.

Now, see the first secret. Because the base of a pyramid is a square, half of the base is equal to the distance from the pyramid's true center to the midpoint of the base. This line will be the base of our hidden triangle!
Return to the midpoint on the face. Now measure the second line that is knowable: the distance from the midpoint of the base up to the apex.
The triangle is now revealed. You have leg 'a' (205.5) and hypotenuse 'c' (342.5). The final, unmeasurable side is the one we seek: the true vertical height, leg 'b'.
You now have the formula: bÂ² = cÂ² - aÂ². To find the height 'b' itself, what must you do next?
Your formula is bÂ² = cÂ² - aÂ². You know the slant 'c' is 342.5 and the half-base 'a' is 205.5. 342.5Â² - 205.5Â² is equal to 75,076.
You have found bÂ² = 75,076. Now, release the true height from its squared form.
Behold the dimensions: Half-base 205.5, Height 274, Slant 342.5. Divide all by 68.5 and see the harmony.

You have used measurement, rationality and the Pythagorean Theorem to discover the hidden ratio of the Great Pyramid of Khafre, built 2000 years before our time! Congratulations, you are now a Pythagorean!

myia.name: Myia
dialogues: This is a monochord. See these two strings? Click the blue string on the left to hear its tone.
Now click the yellow string on the right. It is exactly half the lengthâ€”a ratio of 1:2.
This ratio is called an octave. The same note, but higher. Press play to hear both the notes at the same time.
Interesting, that the ratio of the two strings changes the feeling of the sound. Not all of the sounds are so nice, are they? Try the ratio of 2:3. Thatâ€™s another nice combination.
You've learned well, Apprentice! Now for your final test: I will play a mystery harmony. Listen carefully, then select which ratio creates this sound.
Excellent ear! You've proven you understand the mathematics of harmony!

myia.name: Myia
dialogues: Letâ€™s start with even and odd numbers. All even numbers can form a perfect rectangle in two rows. Odd numbers always have one left over.
But, some numbers are specialâ€”they can form perfect squares. Nine, for example, makes a square with 3 pebbles on each side. But 10 canâ€™t. Try it yourself! You can add the rows to make the square.
Great! That's why three times three is called "three squared."
Now I will teach you the most sacred shape of my father. What is 1+2+3+4?

Correct! Now we can place ten pebbles to build the shape of the Tetractys. Start with one pebble at the top, then two below it, three next, and four on the next row. You can add the rows to make the triangle.
The rowsâ€”one, two, three, fourâ€”add up to ten. It represents the building blocks of our universe: the point, the line, the plane, and the solid.
This shows that math itself is harmoniousâ€”and that the universe is built from numbers. Now letâ€™s put what we have learnt into action. Take the quiz to move forward.

Congratulations, Apprentice! You have successfully completed your initiation into the Pythagorean mysteries. Through the music of ratios and the geometry of shapes, you have begun to understand how numbers govern the universe. Remember: 'All is number' - Pythagoras

  • Simple ratios sound more harmonious than complex ones
  • Watch how frequency values update as you adjust settings

info.title: About the Monochord
info.content:
Pythagoras used this simple instrument to discover that music follows mathematical laws.

How it works:

  • One string stretched over a resonating box
  • Moving the bridge divides the string into different lengths
  • Shorter lengths = higher pitches
  • The ratio determines the musical interval

Key discoveries:

  • 2:1 ratio = octave (same note, higher)
  • 3:2 ratio = perfect fifth (very harmonious)
  • 4:3 ratio = perfect fourth (also harmonious)
  • Simple ratios with small numbers sound better

This became the foundation of music theory and showed that mathematics creates beauty.

help.title: How to use this tool?
help.content:
• Watch how the pebbles arrange into patterns.
  • In the first mode, pebbles line up in two rows.
    • Even numbers make perfect rectangles with no gaps.
    • Odd numbers always leave one pebble unpaired.
  • In the next modes, try building different shapes:
    • Squares and Triangles: Click on the button "Add row" to add a new row.

Tips:

  • Try numbers like 9, 16, 25 to see perfect squares
  • Try numbers like 3, 6, 10, 15 to see perfect triangles
  • Notice how some numbers work for both shapes

info.title: About pebble mathematics
info.content:
Ancient Greeks used pebbles to understand number patterns before written mathematics existed.

Even and odd numbers:

  • Even numbers split into two equal groups
  • Odd numbers always have one left over
  • This creates symmetric vs asymmetric arrangements

Figurate numbers:

  • Triangular numbers: 1, 3, 6, 10, 15, 21...
  • Square numbers: 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36...
  • These numbers form perfect geometric shapes with pebbles

This hands-on method helped ancient mathematicians understand number properties we still use today.

help.title: How to use this tool?
help.content:
• Select a Pythagorean triple (3-4-5, 6-8-10, or 5-12-13) from the buttons
  • Click "Calculate & Animate" to see the pebbles move into position
  • Watch as pebbles from the two smaller squares rearrange into the largest square
  • Try different triples to see the theorem work with various numbers

What you're seeing:

  • Red square shows a2 pebbles
  • Blue square shows b2 pebbles
  • Green square shows c2 pebbles
  • Animation proves that a2 + b2 = c2

info.title: About the pebble proof
info.content:
Ancient Greeks used pebbles to understand math before modern algebra existed.

The Pythagorean Theorem:

  • In any right triangle: a2 + b2 = c2
  • a and b are the legs, c is the hypotenuse

Why it works:

  • Each pebble represents one unit
  • Squares show squared numbers visually
  • Moving pebbles proves the two smaller squares equal the largest
  • Works for any Pythagorean triple like 3-4-5 or 6-8-10

help.title: How to use this tool?
help.content:
• Use sliders to adjust values of a and b
  • Click "Pour A" to empty blue square into gray square
  • Click "Pour B" to empty red square into gray square
  • Mouse wheel to zoom, click and drag to pan
  • "Reset" to try again with different values

Tips:

  • Try different values to see the theorem always works
  • Notice the equation updates automatically
  • Water shows that a2 + b2 = c2

info.title: About the pouring proof
info.content:
This visual proof uses water to show the Pythagorean Theorem through area.

How it works:

  • Each square's area equals the square of its side length
  • Water volume represents the numerical area
  • The two smaller squares' water perfectly fills the largest square
  • This proves a2 + b2 = c2 for any right triangle

Why water works:

  • Unlike pebbles, water fills any shape and works for all numbers, not just whole numbers. This bridges concrete proofs with abstract math

help.title: How to use this tool?
help.content:
• Use sliders to adjust the legs a and b of the right triangle
  • Click "Rearrange" to move the four triangles between positions
  • Watch how the same four triangles fit around different squares
  • The first arrangement shows c2 (tilted green square)
  • The second arrangement shows a2 + b2 (blue and orange squares)

Tips:

  • Try different values to see this works for any right triangle
  • Notice the four triangles are identical in both arrangements
  • The total area stays the same only the shape changes

info.title: About the dissection proof
info.content:
This elegant proof shows the Pythagorean Theorem by rearranging identical pieces.

How it works:

  • Four identical right triangles are arranged around a square
  • In the first position, they surround the c2 square (hypotenuse)
  • In the second position, they surround the a2 and b2 squares (legs)
  • The total area stays the same, proving a2 + b2 = c2

This visual proof requires no numbers or calculations just pure geometric reasoning that convinced ancient mathematicians.

help.title: How to use this tool?

info.title: About the City Wall problem
info.content:
This medieval-themed quest teaches the Pythagorean theorem through a practical scenario: finding the ladder length needed to scale a castle wall across a moat.

The math:

  • Wall height = one leg (a)
  • Moat width = other leg (b)
  • Ladder length = hypotenuse (c)
  • Apply the Pythagorean theorem to solve the problem
  • The interactive walks you through each step: squaring the sides, adding them, and finding the square root

Real-world use:

  • Firefighters use this to position ladders safely
  • Construction workers apply it for scaffolding setup
  • Rescue teams rely on it for access planning
  • Anytime you need to reach a height while keeping a safe base distance, the Pythagorean theorem provides the answer

  • Once correct, you'll automatically move to the next step.
  • Complete all steps to finish the initiation.

Tips:

  • Pay close attention to the 3D pyramid model.
  • Remember: squaring a number means multiplying it by itself.

Definitions to know:

  • A cubit is an ancient unit of measurement roughly equal to the length of a forearm.
  • An apex is the highest point or vertex of a pyramid.

info.title: About the Pyramid Problem
info.content:
This ancient-themed quest teaches the Pythagorean theorem through a practical scenario: finding the hidden, true height of the Great Pyramid using only measurements taken from the outside.

The Math:

  • Half the base width = one leg (a)
  • The true vertical height = other leg (b)
  • The measurable slant height = hypotenuse (c)
  • Using the theorem: a2 + b2 = c2
  • This interactive walks you through each step: isolating the hidden triangle, rearranging the formula, squaring the sides, and finding the final square root to reveal the height.

Real-world Use:

  • This principle is used by surveyors, architects, and astronomers to measure everything from mountains to the cosmos.
